title: Uphill Nature Reserve Walking Route

images.title: Boats, cliff and the old St Nicholas's church, Uphill by Ruth Sharville, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Boats, cliff and the old St Nicholas's church, Uphill

images.title: Chris Downer / Uphill: remains of windmill
images.caption: Uphill: remains of windmill. Not instantly recognisable as a windmill now, but it is open and thus allows an even higher vantage point from which to take in the fine views.

images.title: Uphill Great Rhyne by Derek Harper, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Uphill Great Rhyne

images.title: Martin Bodman / Weston-super-Mare: boatyard at Uphill
images.caption: Weston-super-Mare: boatyard at Uphill. Looking roughly north west with Brean Down in the distance; the hill belongs to the National Trust and is across the river Axe from Uphill

images.title: Chris Downer / Uphill: beacon and Severn view
images.caption: Uphill: beacon and Severn view. This beacon, clearly sponsored by British Gas, stand atop the beacon. Beyond is the church and the Severn estuary.

images.title: Sarah Charlesworth / St Nicholas Church on its rock above Uphill beach road
images.caption: St Nicholas Church on its rock above Uphill beach road

images.title: Stream at Uphill by Ruth Sharville, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Stream at Uphill village.

description: This walk explores the pretty nature reserve in Uphill, just south of Weston-Super-Mare on the Somerset coast. The route also visits the remains of the Uphill windmill and climbs to Uphill Beacon for nice views over the area. You can start the walk from the car parking area on the southern outskirts of Uphill village. Then pick up trails heading south past the pretty boating marina to Walborough. The route then turns around and heads north to climb Uphill Beacon where you'll find the old windmill. There's great views to enjoy from here towards the coast and surrounding Mendip Hills. The route then descends past the old St Nicholas' church which is perched on an unusual large rock above the village. From here it is a short stroll back down to the car park.
